If the wrong report wasn't enough, the doctor who released us from the ER must not have even looked at the images and was just based on the wrong report.  Or, if he looked, he also didn't know how to interpret the images, as he informed us that neither crack nor fracture had occurred.  But the worst was later: we returned to the ER at Hospital Samaritano a week later, with my mother reporting an absurd increase in pain. The pain, which was previously more in the costal region, spread intensely to both legs.  In other words, any layman would have raised the alarm: an 84-year-old woman who had all the CT scans, was treated and returned to the ER a week later, reporting an absurd increase in pain, cannot be seen as something normal.  The minimum expected course of action would be for the doctor to re-examine the CT scans and, if necessary, request an urgent MRI.  Well, we were seen by an orthopedic doctor, who didn't even examine my mother and just gave the verdict: it was a pinched sciatic nerve!  He prescribed an injection of Diprospan and released us!  It takes a lot of incompetence to act like that.  I, a layman, have already learned from this single experience.  Now, imagine an experienced doctor who has seen hundreds of cases like this, not taking any precautions, not re-examining the images and not even requesting an MRI!!!  How can someone who acts with such negligence call themselves a doctor!  Well, my mother returned home, we increased the dosages of neuropathic medications and none of the pain reduced.  Finally, we went to the ER at Hospital Samaritano for a third time and only then were we lucky enough to be seen by a competent doctor, who examined my mother and ordered an MRI, which would clearly indicate the fracture.  The same fracture that was already apparent and easy to see on the initial CT scans.  This delay in detecting the problem hurt my mother a lot and was caused by 3 incompetent doctors working in the same place, the PS at Hospital Samaritano, which I wouldn't recommend even to my worst enemy!
